title: AudioBERTScore: Objective Evaluation of Environmental Sound Synthesis Based on Similarity of Audio Embedding Sequences
author: Minoru Kishi (Keio University), Ryosuke Sakai (Keio University), Shinnosuke Takamichi (Keio University), Yusuke Kanamori (The University of Tokyo), Yuki Okamoto (The University of Tokyo)
relevance_why: The proposed AudioBERTScore metric for evaluating synthesized audio directly aligns with Haohe Liu's interests in audio synthesis and quality assessment, particularly in the context of text-to-audio generation.
background: Evaluating synthesized environmental sounds based on their similarity to reference audio using embedding sequences extracted from audio models.
contribution: This paper introduces AudioBERTScore to solve the problem of insufficient correlations in existing evaluation metrics for synthesized audio, achieving a higher correlation with subjective evaluation scores.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous metrics like Mel-Cepstral Distortion and WARP-Q provide weak correlations to subjective evaluations, limiting their effectiveness.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances evaluation accuracy by employing both max-norm and p-norm methods for analyzing audio embedding sequences, allowing for capturing both local and non-local sound characteristics.

key_innovation: The dual-norm approach to similarity scoring captures both localized and distributed audio information, improving the evaluation of complex environmental sounds.
real_world_impact: The method has the potential to enhance evaluation practices in audio synthesis, benefiting applications in media content creation, gaming, and virtual reality environments.
limitations: The study does not fully address how AudioBERTScore can be universally applied to all audio types, suggesting room for improvement.

new_terms.max-norm: **Max-norm** refers to a measure that takes the maximum similarity score, assuming locality in the data.
new_terms.p-norm: **P-norm** is a generalization of measuring distances that can emphasize local features or provide a more holistic view of similarity based on the parameter p.

open_sourcing: The code is open-sourced at the project's GitHub page: https://github.com/lourson1091/audiobertscore
